awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Carnegie Supernova Project - Pushing the Precision of Type Ia Supernovae as Cosmological Standard Candles
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research on an extensive dataset that will provide firm tests of the types of stars that end their life as Type Ia supernovae.  The researchers will recalibrate data to higher precision and gain a better understanding of systematic errors and uncertainties.  Results from this work will help provide tests of general relativity and improve our understanding of dark energy.  Graduate students and postdoctoral researchers will be trained and mentored in research. Public outreach programs incorporating research results will be carried out at the home institutions of the PIs. The final reduced data will be made available to the astronomical community. 

This project will be accomplished by completing data reduction of optical and near-infrared wavelength images to produce final light curves of supernova explosions. They will also complete data reduction of near-infrared spectra of supernova explosions with an emphasis on improved removal of telluric absorption. They will produce new spectral templates for the community, analyze host galaxy properties, and produce Hubble diagrams. Finally, they will compare theory with observation and look for evidence of interaction with non-degenerate companions or circumstellar material. They will also probe the explosion physics as a function of luminosity and light curve decline rate. The dataset will also be used to improve the precision of using supernova Type Ia data as distance indicators for constraining the nature of dark energy.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

 

The High-Z Supernova Team and the Supernova Cosmology Project surprised the world scientific community with the discovery of the accelerated expansion of the Universe, often called Dark Energy. The concept is simple: you can calculate how far you travel by knowing your velocity and how long you drive. In cosmology, it is easy to measure velocity. We call this redshift. We also know the age of the Universe. Thus, conceptually, we can calculate the distance to galaxies in our expanding Universe. We must correct for gravity in cosmology, however. Since gravity slows things down (a ball thrown in the air slows down and falls back because of the Earth's gravity), we expect that the Universe is also decelerating over time due to the mutual gravitational interaction of galaxies.

 

Thus, we were shocked when we found that instead of the expansion of the Universe slowing down over time, it was accelerating as if anti-gravity dominated the Universe. Einstein had toyed with this idea in his 1917 modification of his general theory of relativity. He added a constant representing an additional acceleration or deceleration, a property of empty space. He later set this constant to zero, finding it was not needed for his models of cosmology.

 

But that constant, called Lambda, was always in the equations. Our teams (I co-founded the HZT with Brian Schmidt) found that this constant is non-zero and slightly positive, indicating that the Universe is presently dominated by this ad hoc Dark Energy, and its evolution is governed by anti-gravity. At a cosmic scale, a ball thrown upward does not fall back down but continues to climb higher and higher, faster and faster. The cumulative effect of Dark Energy integrated over cosmic distances is so large that starting about 5 billion years ago, Dark Energy surpassed normal attractive gravity and will dominate the entire future of the Universe. It accounts for 70% of the mass/energy of the Universe. With 70% of the Universe's Dark Energy and 26% of the Universe an unexplained Dark Matter, we are left with only 4% of our Universe, which is made of normal stuff such as protons, electrons, photons, and all the subatomic particles. We have not explained what is causing that 96% of missing matter and energy.

 

This result relies on our calibration of the distances to galaxies using a type of exploding star called a Type Ia supernova. My group, the Cal?n/Tololo Supernova Survey, in the 1990s, had discovered how to use this type of explosion to measure distances with 6% accuracy. Cosmology has advanced since then, and the accuracy required to discover Dark Energy 25 years ago is insufficient for today's cosmology. This NSF grant was awarded to improve the calibration of the luminosities of Type Ia explosions and provides a second sample of supernovae "CSPII" to be added to our first sample CSPI, funded by a previous NSF grant. The new sample addressed several issues.

 

First and foremost, we needed a sample of hundreds of new supernovae measured using the same equipment and calibrated using the same accurate standard stars of known brightness. Second, we needed to calibrate precisely what wavelengths are being observed when using a particular instrumental setup, something we call the "transmission function." Finally, we needed to add more data taken in the near infrared.

 

There are astrophysical questions that also need new data. What are the effects of dust in our Galaxy and the galaxy that hosted the exploding star? Is this interstellar dust like the dust in our part of the Galaxy? Are there Type Ia explosions that lie outside of our calibrations? Finally, with improved data, what is the expansion rater of the Universe ? the Hubble-Lema?tre constant?

 

Results:

 

  1. We have provided the community with data on over 400 exploding stars in CSPI and CSPII. In this second CSPII sample, we have added 134 Type Ia supernovae and over 100 massive star supernovae.
  2. We have provided the specific transmission curves which define the photometric data, which we measured in situ at the telescope.
  3. We have found a class of blue luminous Type Ia supernovae that do not fit the calibration and must be accounted for in any cosmological survey using supernovae.
  4. We have explored the nature of dust obscuration and found that many supernovae have smaller-than-average dust grains even when measured with near-infrared photometry.
  5. We find the value of the Hubble-Lema?tre constant to range from 71.4 to 72.6 km/s/Mpc combining all calibration techniques and 68.5 to 74.6 for individual techniques, pointing to significant uncertainties between the Cepheid, TRGB, and SBF methods.
